instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
Hi,

I received this MacBook with a not turning on issue.
They said it wasn't liquid damaged just one day stopped working.
I'm sure it wasn't dropped, because the MacBook looks pristine.

However I'm not sure if it wasn't liquid damaged. There aren't discolored pads on the board.
However around the components I can see some "wet" spots. No corrosion or anything. Just like it was immediately cleaned after a liquid damage.
I'm not sure if it makes any sense. :)

There is a short on this board. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground. I can't find the shorted component(s) if there is any.
I sent through 5A this board, but the voltage drop is really big. If it would be a shorted cap or any components I think that component should glow for now.
0.6V at 5A, but I've 0.45V voltage drop through the cables. Which are speaker cables(the thicker one). I've lipo battery here, but I can't control the voltage and I just don't want to set the board on fire.

What should I do?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: Leave the board powered for a while like that. Then use your lips to feel for something hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message:
I left it on the PSU almost 2 hours and still can't feel anything even with my lips. I'm clueless. I don't know what should I use there.
0.3 Ohm short.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: I have no idea. Crank it up to 10amp, could be a short in the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: I limited to 5A. My old PSU can't do more unfortunately.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: Well, you need to get something else, there is no magic to find a short. Use an old motherboard that still powers on. The GPU or CPU Vcore supply can deliver lots of amps at <2V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shorted to ground
threads.message: Good idea. I'll try that definitely!
